pros: Students were mostly a pleasure to teach: thoughtful, creative, passionate.
cons:
But faculty have a lot on their plate, and I received next to no training from my "mentor." Ended up trying being the leader/organizer of my research team, even though I was the most inexperienced member on it.

There is a curious lack of standardization in teaching as well, which places a lot of burden on each individual instructor to create their own evaluation metrics for each class. This does not serve the students, nor the faculty.

Finally the administration at the top of the university has recently changed hands, and this has resulted in a lot of disruption and chaos for some departments, especially those in STEM, as they are seemingly not valued by the current administration, who appears to care more about instituting change rather than the effects of those changes. 

In addition, because it's academia, there is really no outlet to voice criticism.

job_title: Research Assistant I in Nashville, TN
pros: Vanderbilt is obviously a place of leading, cutting edge medical research, so being a part of their impact while honing my own niche and gifts in research is an experience of a lifetime. The lead staff who perform research here are highly competent, talented, and knowledgeable, and it is an honor working under their mentorship and guidance. I cannot stress enough the extent of career opportunities and connections that come with working here. Vanderbilt is likely the best starting place for the ambitious researcher or grad student. However, this is a place someone with a degree should work to gain that experience so that they can branch off and find better career opportunities elsewhere.
cons:
When it comes to workers who aren't lead staff, the wages are kept severely too low and do not match level of competency or experience. As I transition to a Research Assistant II, nearing 4 total years of research experience, I am being underpaid by more than 25% of Nashville's proposed base average for my position, and even paid less than what a beginner level Research Assistant should. I have to keep extra part-time jobs just to maintain financial security to live in Nashville in 2022. 

HR here is also extremely difficult when it comes to any decision. I have never seen such a slow-working yet overly bureaucratic system. HR made it unnecessarily difficult for me just to get hired despite my boss's offer for the position. After working here for over a year and a half, they also declined the small raise that my boss proposed with my promotion, which DOES NOT happen in the workplace, ever (even though I would still be underpaid for the position that I hold now).

review_title: Vanderbilt University masquerades as a top employer but relies on its academic laurels to lure in new employees
pros: There are pockets within Vanderbilt that are great. I have some amazing colleagues within my department and across campus. I recommend doing as much research as possible before deciding to join Vanderbilt, especially as more employment opportunities become available in Nashville and beyond.
cons:
Vanderbilt University does a great job hiding its staff culture behind its academic reputation; working here is a different story. Vanderbilt trails the private sector and other academic institutions in many categories (pay, benefits, perks, technology, strategy). Benefits are touted as outstanding, but they aren’t. The tuition benefit is laughable, up to 70% reimbursement per class per semester. Good luck if you are on a reasonable track. Pay lags both higher education and private sector, and you’ll be doing the job of two people as Vanderbilt runs lean (assuming all of the pay is being funneled to the executive leaders who are paid quite well, which you can find online). 

As others have stated, promotions are based on popularity as metrics and objective measuring points are non-existent. Unfortunately, the University does a great job of conducting layoffs; it seems every department is constantly being reorganized, and leadership turnover occurs often. The only constant at Vanderbilt is change. One of these departments is HR, which lacks adequate, consistent leadership and has for the past few years; we are now on our fourth CHRO in a few years (and they’re still trying to figure out how to support the institution effectively). There has also been significant turnover in the Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion space, even though Vanderbilt believes they thought leaders. 

When working here, I always feel caught in the “tides” of Vanderbilt University’s political views and initiatives (you can fact check by looking at who they donate to for political races). If you don’t fit the Vanderbilt mold, you will be singled out. It also seems there are cases where hiring is made on visual appearances rather than experience, education, and credentials in the pursuit of “diversity.”

pros: The benefits are great with PTO split into vacation and sick time.  It is "hit or miss" as if you find the right department and right boss you will be in great shape.
cons:
Don't work for a professor!  I provided IT expertise as part of my boss's research group and his utter inability to recognize the difference between staff and graduate students was problematic:

- 8 hours worth of meetings and seminars every week, including one every late Friday
- Professor assumed full time staff had the same passion and knowledge of his subjects as his graduate students and expected me to take classes (that did not happen, by the way).
- Too many performance reviews (1 month, 3 month, 6 month, 1 year)
- No work from home options, even though the software development and nature of the work did not require a 100% on-site presence.
- "Graduate student drama" which resulted in duplicate efforts among research group members and myself.
- I had over half a dozen major projects going on at any given time with deadlines that could not be achieved.  See the first item again.
- No one could ever provide sufficient justification for why we get charged high parking permit fees and why we cannot even park close to our offices.

pros: Vandy is a big place, and mileage varies from department to department. I work at the engineering research group ISIS. Opportunities to learn and expand have been great. Coworkers are wonderful, friendly, helpful, and extremely competent. Projects are interesting in that we research and create new things from scratch. The general work attitude is, "That's the mountain of work. Grab a shovel, and start digging anywhere that looks good." Most of the time it's a fairly relaxed environment. When a project first starts, we run a thousand miles an hour with our hair on fire to bootstrap the situation. Then things calm down nicely. New project management has been instituted to reduce and in most cases eliminate the crazy times. It's also helped our production. So both management and worker bees are happy with that situation.
cons: We're still part of the greater Vandy community so we're stuck with poor senior level management decisions. Many rules make sense for the medical center side but are nonsense in a university setting. Benefits have been slashed, but we're told it's good for us. Pay has stagnated. Compensation while once highly competitive is now behind the times.

review_title: Needs major cultural shift at the top.
pros:
Experiences at Vanderbilt differ dramatically depending on division and department. My review reflects my experience within student affairs. 
-Bright, committed colleagues at the junior staff level. 
-For those with supportive supervisors, there are opportunities to sit on interesting committees and subsequently take on additional responsibility, gain exposure to other areas within the division, and find mentors.
-A dynamic, challenging, fun student body
-Significant professional development funds for conferences, trainings, etc.
cons:
-Substantially lower pay when compared to peer institutions in cities with similar or lower cost-of-living.
-Reactive and anxious senior management (again, within student affairs, though not broadly at the university) - this characteristic of senior admins creates a fairly negative, anxiety-filled culture. Unfortunately, bureaucratic, inflexible, and risk-adverse management also prevents staff members from taking steps to address issues within their departments proactively.
-No work/life balance. Expectation is that staff are available 24/7, including when on vacation. 
-Inconsistency in policy enforcement across division (ex. some managers allow staff to use informal flex time when working long hours, others allow NO flex time).

pros: This small office has a team of talented staff dedicated to assisting undergraduates. The larger University offers a wealth of resources and each person I've encountered is happy to share information or advice.
cons: The administrative/leadership team in this office is very much into maintaining the status quo and keeping up appearances. Staff are encouraged to be entrepreneurial but leadership struggles with making decisions in a timely manner or requiring so much validation that the project owner loses interest. Moral and enthusiasm are often poor and little is done to acknowledge or remedy the situation. My perception is that leadership is more willing to put more time in finding a replacement than coaching a staff member struggling in their role. Not very much done in the way of staff perks, in fact student workers are given more attention than paid staff! There is also an 'hourly mentality' with regard to staff schedules, and taking time off or being out of the office.

job_title: Research Analyst I in Nashville, TN
pros: You get  a paycheck
cons: Professor misrepresents the job.  This individual will also record what you are doing without your permission.  This is a research assistant position that has intentionally been re-named as a Research Analyst to attract people who have strong background experience.  They will not allow you to serve as a PI, or a co-PI, if you do not have a Ph.D.  That IS the difference between a Research Analyst position and being a lab monitor who does research.  This job is the latter - a lab monitor position who will be expected to hand over ideas & methodologies to the extremely entitled students as well as to the professor, who want them for themselves.  If you take this job, you will not benefit from the work you do.  The professor's & the university will make sure of that.  You're basically going to be a tutor for over paid faculty.  This is a toxic environment.  I deeply regret ever taking this position & ever dealing with this university.

review_title: Unethical place; don't apply here if you care about student needs
pros: Time between Christmas and New Year's are holidays for staff, so you don't have to use PTO to cover them.
cons:
There are many cons to working here, but the ones that come to mind the most are:
- Lack of transparency: My office is about to hire a director. The university is hiring an outside consultant to select candidates; the actual staff in my office will not have any part to play until the finalists are brought to campus. It says a lot that the university feels it can trust an outsider more than the people who do the day-to-day gruntwork.
- Lack of concern about students:  Vanderbilt likes to pride itself on its commitment to students, but this place is hardly at all student-centric. We have had students repeatedly come to us with concerns about food insecurity, financial instability, and racial/ethnic bias on campus. Those concerns fall on deaf ears. Sure, it's great that the campus has banned plastic straws, but don't pat yourself on the back when students dumpster-dive for food.
- Lack of concern for staff: A colleague who was putting in 20-hours days was still grilled by upper administration for "not working hard enough." If you ask for the occasional flex time, you will be told that since you are exempt, you are not eligible for flex time.

review_title: Vanderbilt wants to be run in an efficient, business-like manner, but the internal political climate won't allow it.
pros: Vanderbilt has an excellent benefits package.  My co-workers were excellent employees.  Also, we always had the latest equipment available for our use.
cons: Vanderbilt suffers from intense political strife, which leads to much confusion among the employees.  You don't know if your job is "safe", and it is a day-to-day concern.  Recently, management suspended vacation accrual for 3 months.  Additionally, hiring was frozen until the end of the fiscal year.  It is apparent some mis-management has occurred in upper level management.  There seems to be a lack of empathy for the lab employees role by upper management.

pros: Winter break, PTO, Workload (at times), Student Athletes, resume builder
cons: Staff, Senior Leadership, Lack of Management skills , NO PROMOTIONS, no transferrable skills but at least you have Vanderbilt name, management will not teach you anything to help you grow and rate you for not challenging them, if you’re a young female you will get accused of inappropriate relationships  with the athletes (laughing together is BAD) , cant be openly close to staff in other departments because senior leaders don’t like each other (only friend your department or you will be disliked), try not to smile people here dont like happy people, your job description means nothing when the turnover rate is so high be ready to do what is asked but don’t worry you will never get recognized or thanked for going above and beyond but if you dont do its a negative/average rate on proformace reviews

job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: Some of the brightest minds in research and good reputation for research overall.  Established track record for receiving NIH funds.  Big push to find the most advanced technologies in healthcare.
cons: Huge cutback on employee benefits for staff was rather insensitive to the needs of those employees not fortunate enough to hold a PhD or MD degree. Even the latter employees were not immune as many were cut if they could not garner enough outside funds. This put a huge damper on employee morale.  In what was once  a highly collaborative environment, this pressure makes the academic research more competitive than ever, in the long run, slowing the advances in medicine.

review_title: An organization that used to, at least, appreciate and respect its employees

cons: With cuts in NIH funding and reimbursements for healthcare, it's a really difficult time for Vanderbilt economically, especially for a place that once had "more money than God". I've also heard that the recent layoffs were not handled as respectfully as they might have been.

review_title: Training abounds, workload but pay & benefits never increase substantially
pros: There are plenty of skills to learn here and people are friendly and helpful. Flexible schedules for most careers of this type here.
cons: Pay does not keep pace with inflation even with perfect job performance reviews, expanding responsibilities, and for some tasks becoming virtually irreplaceable.

review_title: Lots of benefits, but organizational structure puts employees at a disadvantage.
job_title: Research Analyst I in Nashville, TN
pros: Many jobs at Vanderbilt have flexible scheduling, autonomous work environment, excellent healthcare benefits, and helpful on the job training programs and workshops.
cons: The organizational system at Vanderbilt often means that others will be managed by someone who is not "officially" their manager. This creates a situation where you several "bosses" who may ask opposing things of you, and write your performance reviews even though they have no contact with you 90% of the time. Also, it seems that human resources has little concern about fairness when it comes to employee promotion and pay. They will offer you less than what your manager has said you qualify for every time. This leads to a lot of people having to transfer into the desired position in another department.

pros: Located in the heart of Nashville, an amazing city to live in.  Vanderbilt is a highly reputable place with great undergrad students.
cons: This is a place where great people come to destroy their careers.   The rapid rise of this place leaves the senior faculty far less accomplished than the junior faculty, leading politics to govern most critical decisions.  The university leadership puts diversity on display, but behind the scenes this place is toxic with discrimination, unfair treatment, and lack of upward mobility for those who are not part of the local gentlemens club.  Overall, if you plan on being single, if you are male, and you are happier being mediocre and part of the club rather than excelling with visibility in the greater community - this is a place for you!  Check out their recent tenure decisions that have gained national prominence in the news and major scientific journals.  That says everything.

pros: Great resources, from career advice, seminars, retreats, programs, Core instruments, etc. You never need to go to a conference because every week there are a ton of external and internal speakers that talk about various subjects (but of course you should go to a conference). Everyone is friendly and works hard, but it's still relatively laidback (you work hard but you can still go out for lunch or visit some departmental party for a drink). The campus is very safe and located in a great area slightly outside Nashville.
cons: At the postdoc level, it might be a bit difficult to advance past your project into an independent project. Of course this really depends on the PI... but it can get slightly competitive here. In order to succeed, you need to be able to work hard but also think about yourself.

review_title: A culture obsessed with ranking but not with doing good work
pros: Good Location in a nice neighborhood in Nashville.
cons: The management is underhanded, Parasitic and overpaid.  The university loses money due to farcical administrative blunders, then they make up for it by cutting benefits, pay, vacation/sick time and retirement.  The cuts are strickly carried out on lower level employees.  Worse still, they make the cuts in 'tricky' ways, thinking that staff are too dumb to notice.  The university has a snobbish culture, wherein every faculty thinks they are a 'star', even as most of them do unimpressive work, play publication and grant games, and schmooze around instead of doing good science, scholarship or teaching.  The pay seems ok for academic work, but rent, housing, food and other costs are quite high in Nashville, making the pay effectively poor unless you want to spend a lot of time commuting on congested highways.

pros: Good benefits. Most of the staff are friendly. Beautiful campus. The reputation precedes itself. The experience Looks great on your resume and a number of softwares are used at other universities which will serve likely to your advantage. Given the size of campus, you are given the opportunity to transition elsewhere and encouraged to utilize available resources.
cons: Pay is below the National average in terms of what you’d be making virtually anywhere else.  Training is minimal And non existent is most areas. Extensive social networking is necessary in order to create upward mobility. Overall campus wide Job satisfaction is relatively low. The expectation in terms of job performance and time commitment does not match salary.

review_title: Great place to do graduate research in any biomedical field
pros: Cutting-edge research, PhD students receive highly-competitive stipends, free health insurance, rec. center, and waiver of tuition
cons: Academic researchers aren't fully focused on training and preparing you for your next career move.  They're focused on getting funding and doing research.

review_title: Good for Faculty, bad for Staff
pros: Good pay and medical benefits. If you're lucky, your manager will be inattentive enough to allow you to work.
cons: Extremely political work environment. More time is spent making yourself look like you're making progress than actually making progress. Management loves to brag about "open-minded" culture, but it couldn't be further from the truth. Terrible hierarchy where faculty are treated like royalty and staff are expendable. Any attempts to improve efficiency are shot down in order to create more work. The worst part is the haughty attitude everyone seems to have about it all. Prestige and popularity is more important than results.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: Vanderbilt has great opportunities to conduct groundbreaking research. The pay for graduate researchers is comparable to that offered at other peer universities. Nashville is a nice city to live in, and Vanderbilt is at a good location.
cons: Department-level administration cares much less about performing their administrative duties than about continuing their ongoing research projects, so management can range from clueless to negligent. The administration offers no proactive measures to help to students who are struggling in the graduate program, allowing graduate students to fail without offering anything in the way of support.

job_title: Business Intelligence Analyst in Nashville, TN
pros: Employee gym access is the only benefit I can think of as a pro.
cons:
The benefits are below what is usually given for higher ed - 401k or 403a-b contribution, health insurance, etc.

The cultural in my department was too top heavy with extreme pressure to be perfect despite having no guidance from management.  Furthermore there was a disconnect to build relationships between employees.  I felt like there was little time or events to socialize.  It was constantly work in front of my screen and little down time.

review_title: One of the best positions I've ever held.
job_title: Research Assistant II in Nashville, TN
pros:
(Bear in mind, there are hundreds of departments, labs, etc., all of them different.)

My lab, which generally encompassed between 6 and 12 people at any time, was like the most interesting startup possible, working for (and with) extremely intelligent people, with no corporate BS *whatsoever*.

Entirely results-based, total ownership of your own work, occasional thank-yous in published research papers.
cons:
University work doesn't pay as much as the commercial sector, which is fine by me!
Also, if your position is funded by a grant, those expire and are sometimes not renewed.

pros:
Exceptional benefits, including paying the majority of tuition costs for children of employees at any university in the country.
Beautiful campus with a relaxed atmosphere.
Wonderful colleagues from all over the world.
Intellectually challenging.
The name Vanderbilt University is respected and carries prestige with it - which often reflects on you in others eyes.
cons: Compensation is not based on competence or job requirements. An outside hire will automatically be offered 10% more than an internal transfer hire. The medical research staff are paid more than the university research staff. A new hire without experience will make more than a person that has been in the identical position and has 10 years experience.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Nashville, TN
pros: Standard benefit package for health and dental.  Idyllic campus setting.  Low cost of living. Weather is mild except for a  few days in summer.  Belmont and Lipscomb Universities are nearby so a somewhat collegiate atmosphere.
cons: Nashville is not the most cosmopolitan city with very little diversity or culture.  Definitely need a car as the mass transit is substandard.  Downtown is pretty scary.  Ended up working (suffereing) for a professor who came under faculty misconduct investigations for obvious abuses.  Also, had very little interaction with other parts of the university or hospital.

job_title: Lab Teaching Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: Benefits are reasonably good. Being paid hourly allows you to accrue a significant amount (several weeks) of time off throughout the year.
cons: The pay is bad enough to be laughable if it wasn't so insulting. $30k a year for a job that won't hire below the master's level? Insulting. No upward mobility, as well. Pretty much, unless you're in administration, you don't matter; the only thing that really matters is money.

review_title: If you really care about doing a great job, do it for another organization.
pros: Good benefits - 403(b) match, insurance, vacation.  The opportunity to work with some of the best people, for a well - respected organization
cons: Upper management truly does not care for the staff that makes this university really work.  They're all about attracting super star faculty and researchers, but the support staff that actually is hands on doing the work, that really cares about doing good work, is overworked and not supported.  For whatever reason (mostly refusal to invest the needed money) the IT systems are a patchwork of add-ons over a base system installed in the 1980s.

pros: Great people to work with. Seeks and is open to innovative ideas. Motivated and interesting students. With such a large campus lots of resources. Most of the HR Consultants are fabulous.
cons: As with most large organizations, there can be significant red tape and politics. This can slow down the process of trying to impact change or create something new. The pay isn't great either.

pros: If you have issues within your department you can always go to employee services and they will step in and help you out.  I never needed them but other employees in my department did.
cons: The cons depend on each individual department and there managers.  The department I was in was non profit and we were always critized and watched when it came to spending any money.  My department was used as a tool for many other departments and Vanderbilt students for case studies, thesis studies ect and unable to spend the money to make things look good and run as we should.

review_title: Good benefits, but treat employees like numbers
job_title: Patient Access Representative in Nashville, TN
pros: The benefits and pay were fair. There are often rewards and incentives for a job well done.
cons: The standards for employees are very high, and when not met, there are heavy consequences. Never felt important in the grand scheme of things and when I tried to move up after several years there, all I could get was a latteral move. Lunch breaks were only 30 minutes long, and you had to make sure to clock in at the correct time on the dot, every day, otherwise you could get written up.

review_title: Lots of work for little pay
pros: Beautiful campus, great co-workers, solid benefits, nice students
cons: Paying for campus parking (with annual cost increases), job descriptions are always expanding, salaries are VERY low compared to other industries in town with no bonuses and minimal annual increases, no upward mobility  at all in most positions, senior management see all employees as replaceable and we should take whatever we're given and be "grateful for the privilege" of working there

review_title: Nice people, but your responsibilities are misunderstood
job_title: IT Student Worker in Nashville, TN
pros: Boss is really cool and everyone tries their best at their job.
cons: The school professors are very nice, but some other people whom I have helped have treated me like everything (such as wifi connection strength) was my fault or like I worked for them. I also only get trained for the roles I am needed, which is fine, but I wish my training was more well rounded so that whenever I don't know how to do something, it's not a direct representation of how our tech support really is (because they're great).

review_title: excellent university, but stifling work experience
pros:
- great benefits
- work hard to provide good perks
- association with excellent university and medical school
cons:
- extreme difficulty with change or outside the box thinking
- employee morale is low
- managers want to create "small kingdoms" of their own rather than participate in a collaborative approach for the good of entire organization

pros:
1. small class size
2. research oriented university
3. big medical school
4. great medical benefits
It is premier school located in relatively quiet laid back city. The paycheck(for research assistants) is quite good but cost of living is also high. But main thing is that you will always find funds to support you. So if you get admission, be assure that you will graduate without worrying about costs. If some professor is ready to hire you as RA then okay but if not they will keep you as TA. So no worries there.
cons:
Depends on department and adviser/boss
work can be stressful sometimes

review_title: Your best bet for big science in TN
job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Nashville, TN
pros: The biotech boom has yet to truly reach Nashville. If you're engaged in biomedical research in middle Tennessee, VU is the best game going, and it really is pretty good. But truly, if you want to live in Nashville and you're a scientist, where else are you going to work? That said, you'll find really great resources for science and research. Benefits are pretty competitive. In my experience, compensation is relatively flexible on the University side, less so on the VUMC side. If you bring your own funding, you can set your salary within a reasonable range, especially if the funding source allows maximum overheads. This is true of research faculty. Staff have to play from a different, and significantly less rosy script.
cons: VU/VUMC, like other academic institutions, are training scientists faster than new faculty positions can open up. There's a glut of mid-level researchers with PhD training who are facing a very challenging career landscape that may include many years and many post-doc positions. One neglects the notion that university research is a business at their own peril. The institutions have very little loyalty for individuals who either don't have their own funding or aren't valuable to those who do. It's little different than a typical startup or biotech, but it doesn't include equity (putting aside the rare conversation of IP). Promotion tracks rely heavily on how much of a shrinking funding pool a researcher can accumulate.

review_title: Vanderbilt is a wonderful and caring place to work.
pros: My supervisor gives me the autonomy that I need to do a good job.  I never feel like someone is looking over my shoulder.  I have the support to make changes and try new ideas out to benefit my clients and co-workers.  VU is very supportive of the work/life balance and encourages good health.
cons: The university side has very limited holidays compared to other universities.  However, the vacation accural is good and so makes up for it.

pros: Stable company, nice to feel you make a difference to the patients. State of the art technology is nice.
cons: Leadership no longer cares for employees the way they used to. Job security is not what it once was.

review_title: Great for clinical research but limited emphasis on basic research
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Nashville, TN
pros: Some of the brightest people in research are at Vanderbilt.  They have great tools for research and make great strides in bringing new medicines to patients.
cons:
The culture puts MDs on a pedestal.  The PhDs are second class citizens.

As a postdoc I received the standard NIH pay level.  No retirement or any other perks, but that is what you would expect just about anywhere.

Vanderbilt is having some financial problems with the recent changes to healthcare.  I am sure they will adjust eventually.

pros: This was a very fulfilling position which I enjoyed during the entire time I spent there.  The staff was wonderful and the patients were even more grateful for the work we did for them.  It made it a joy to come to work daily!
cons: When your employer starts to make things more of a business than a patient focused initiative, it then makes it hard to come to work everyday.  The only thing that keeps you coming is the patients and the staff.

review_title: Great for students to make extra money
job_title: Central Library Student Worker in Nashville, TN
pros: The job is pretty easy to learn. You're working with mostly students and faculty,  so there are rarely difficult people to deal with (as you might find with other minimum wage jobs). The supervisors are very understanding of students' crazy schedules, and finding someone to cover your shift is pretty easy. The job isn't super demanding, so there is plenty of time to do homework.
cons: The pay isn't great. I put in $9 for the hourly rate because Glass Door doesn't allow fractions, but it's actually $8.5.

review_title: Overall great place for graduate students
pros: Lots of resources. Collaborative environment. 99% of PIs and students are supportive. Great seminars with visiting scientists from around the world. Vandy also does a good job of supportive a strong work/life balance for all students. Excellent career office for interests inside and outside of science.
cons: You will need a car to get around Nashville.Parking on campus is very expensive.

review_title: Love it! but need to move on.
job_title: Research Assistant I in Nashville, TN
pros: The campus is beautiful with state-of-the-art facilities available to do amazing research. The people who study and work there are friendly, supportive and collaboration among labs are common.
cons: The pay is low, too heavily dictated by HR. Promotions/bonuses were non-existent during my time there (2 years), but for those who did get a promotion, it was almost negligible.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: I was a Ph.D. student (Computer Science) major, and had to leave the program on a sabbatical leave because the funding for my research got over. Got to work on a lot of different things.
cons: The research involved no concrete vision/direction from the higher management, and eventually it faltered and suffered a fate of any project with no clear leadership would. Published a few conference paper on the work that I had been doing for 4 years, but apart from that the way the research was being managed was not satisfactory.

review_title: Positive experience as a graduate research assistant at Vanderbilt University.
pros:
Working as a graduate student researcher at Vanderbilt has many benefits.
- Competitive Stipends
- Access to Vanderbilt Medical Center resources if in a biomedical related field
- Smaller lab sizes result in more one-on-one time with advisors
- Easy to collaborate across disciplines 
- Living in Nashville
cons:
- Outside of medical center, may have to go off-site for some resources (specific cleanroom facilities, etc...)
-  Lots of construction currently, but the final product will be worth it.

review_title: Great place to work. Great benefits. Tough to get in. No room for advancement.
pros: Great benefits and typically good people working at the University. Good environment and steady work for whatever your role is.
cons: Upper management not in tune with what is happening in the departments under them. Middle management can be frustrating to deal with. No room for advancement in most jobs there. Pay caps for most jobs.

pros: The benefits are pretty good overall. There are some great people doing great things there and it is exciting to be on the cutting edge of science and healthcare. Nashville is a great place to live and Vanderbilt's campus is beautiful.
cons: With any large company everything takes a long time to happen. Most of the decisions are made from the people who don't really understand what they are deciding on. Little control for the lower management.

review_title: With the right fit, it's great
pros: When you find the right department, Vanderbilt is the best place to work in town. I'm in a department which allows me to have some flexibility in my hours, the benefits are great, there are things to do after work nearby.
cons: Sometimes it is hard to find the right department when you are trying to get your foot in the door here. It's always hard trying to get your foot in the door here, period.

review_title: As a graduate student worker, Vanderbilt has been respectful to me and providing many opportunities.
job_title: Financial Aid Front Desk in Nashville, TN
pros: The coworkers are friendly, management is understanding, and the pay is above minimum wage. It also is providing work experience that will will improve my chances for obtaining a well paying job after graduation.
cons: Like with any company, it all depends on departments, management, and people. The book store was an unfortunate experience with poor management. The financial aid office has proven to be exceptionally better, but there is no room for advancement as a graduate student.

review_title: Hostile, unfair, low pay work environment
job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Nashville, TN
pros: I learned some new skills that I can put on my resume.  Had to take on other duties not related to my job description, but learned from it.
cons: In the department I worked in, the nurses were very hostile and negative.  The management was subpar, and did not care to resolve issues because of the high turn-over.  Low pay for high stress.

review_title: Worked at ISIS, for a DARPA contract.  It was hard
job_title: Enterprise Network Administrator in Nashville, TN
pros:
Smart people.
Good toys.
No strict Schedule.
Vanderbilt has a liberal holiday policy.
cons:
The PI is almost always under the gun from DARPA grant administrators.  And with nary an exception, it always go down hill.
Different groups do not colloborate well.  No over sight to the PIs

review_title: Surrounded by very hardworking individuals.  Supervisors are very cool and accommodating.
job_title: Student Recycling Worker in Nashville, TN
pros: Supervisors are accommodating to students who are working while in school.  Everyone you work around is very friendly and nice.
cons: The pay could be better, but it is typical for an on-campus job at Vanderbilt University.  The weather sometimes makes the job frustrating.

review_title: Vanderbilt is better than average in terms of compensation
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: Vanderbilt pays about the same as other schools, but Nashville is a relatively cheap city that has a lot of cultural stuff you can do for free like free concerts and hiking
cons: Your experience will very a lot depending on your department and lab. Computer Science is segmented across multiple buildings and it can be very hard to find fellow grad students to make friends. Biology students get more chances to meet, but they have to spend more time physically in lab.

job_title: Research Analyst III in Nashville, TN
pros: University setting is great with a central location to city amenities; Connections to the community; my supervisor is flexible and easy to work with; my hours and scheduling are flexible and I'm not required to work outside regular business hours
cons: Some of the processes in the university system are antiquated and inefficient (i.e. Human Resources, etc.); Pay is average or below average; Employees have to pay to park (~$400)

review_title: I was a Research Assistant at Vanderbilt in the Chemistry Department.
job_title: Research Assistant I in Nashville, TN
pros: Very comfortable and friendly environment. Surrounded by a group of brilliant researchers. Encouraging superiors. Well equipped labs with plenty of resources. Beautiful campus. Great places to have a wide variety of food. Lively atmosphere
cons: Poor salary, considering Nashville being a fairly expensive city to live in. Work hours can sometimes be long.

pros: Love this job, it's so much fun and so relaxed. Lots of time to do homework or socialize with the people you're working with, and the work itself is fun.
cons: Don't get as many hours as I want, have to wear a uniform shirt (except that half the time I don't anyway), too many employees

pros: - Good compensation package, good benefits, insurance, dental, 401 (k), good management hierarchy, and opportunities to advance for merit here.
cons: While the management structure is streamlined here I do feel like it is difficult for me to express my opinions and suggestions regarding improvement here.

review_title: Program Coordinator II at law school
job_title: Program Coordinator II in Nashville, TN
pros: Co workers are great. Pay is good compared to other places.
cons: No training, no way to climb the ladder, upper management has no clue what you do do. Pto includes holidays,sick. And vacation days- most places keep holidays separate from earned pto days.  No communication, no one cares. Has the biggest turn over I've e ever seen.I stayed cause I enjoyed what I did as a job and co-workers. But I should of left sooner for less stress and more growth.

pros:
Great hours
Awesome Class
Pay is competitive based on years of experience and professor discretion. Wouldn't have traded the experience for anything and made valuable connections with industry professionals that led to multiple opportunities.
cons: Only 10 hours per week allowed for full time students and the workload can get a bit heavy when attempting to balance with full course load.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: Vanderbilt provides me with numerous opportunities to advance myself academically and personally. On a daily basis I have an opportunity to work with some of the brightest people in the world.
cons: The pay in academic environments is never the best. Also Nashville as a city gets crazy hot during the summer but that's no fault of the university's.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: The location of Vanderbilt university Nashville is a nice place to live. People here is nice and the price of daily goods is low. Vanderbilt is a university with high academic reputation in engineering.
cons: Not as fabulous as urban cities. Airport is small, which is not convenient for the travel. Actually, it is really hard for me to come up with more cons

pros: An intellectually progressive, generally well-led institution; leaders generally prioritize building the institution; tremendous growth of the region; many outstanding faculty; quality of students has dramatically increased over past decade; work environment and benefits generally excellent.
cons: Despite considerable economic and cultural growth of middle Tennessee, Vanderbilt is a relative progressive island in a culturally conservative region.   Health care economics have hurt Vanderbilt University Medical Center and this has led to a separation of VUMC from VU, with negative morale consequences.

pros: great students and supervisors. The supervisors really cater to your schedule, and are very understanding as well as supportive in tough situations.
cons: There are definitely no cons to think of. Something that may be a con is that the hours get less and less throughout the semester once the students get independent, but that is the entire point of the job.

review_title: Great place to build a knowledge base
pros: There is a thriving research community here. You will get so much from attending lunch time lectures, collaborations within the University, and great undergraduate research students to help support new projects.
cons: Like any research university, there's kind of a lab bubble. It can be hard to know where to turn for a 3rd person point of view or advice in the event of an issue within the lab since lab's are like their own little companies.

review_title: Overall great place to work; however, needs some updating
pros: Great benefits. Love the tuition reimbursement for children of staff. Family friendly and health conscious community of workers. Love Thursday's Farmers Market during the Summer.
cons: Directors and Administration frequently make decisions without consulting with the current end-users. Job description are out of date, frequently do not fit current roles. Subsequently, staff are not paid for the work they actually do. Opportunities for advancement are minimal.

pros: Vanderbilt is a great place to work as a graduate student. The stipend is enough to live off of and you get the benefits of the undergraduates such as health care.
cons: You don't however, get the faculty benefits of a 401k, paid time off, etc. but I don't think many students would expect this.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Nashville, TN
pros: The culture is such that you are surrounded by very intelligent individuals and most are quite helpful
cons: Reflecting on my experience here just honestly makes me sad. It could have been so much more. Challenging problems and tough research is expected out of graduate school, but personal insults, gaslighting, and being made to feel inferior on a daily basis should not be part of this.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: Access to top-notch faculty and equipment in a collaborative research environment. Relatively high research stipend paired with manageable cost of living.
cons: As anywhere in scientific research, the support and environment varies drastically from individual lab to lab. Ensure you are in a laboratory where the mentor is focused on your personal and professional development and not strictly their output.

pros: Flexibility in work schedule, benefits, a great deal of responsibility, interesting work
cons: Below market pay, lack of leadership (or poor leadership), no real upward mobility, some departments have such low morale it impacts business.

pros: The people are very dedicated, smart, and friendly.  The physical environment is pleasant and the grounds are beautiful.  Salaries are competitive and benefits are good.
cons: Parking is always a problem and the campus police are diligent on towing cars.  Even catering trucks are hassled when trying to unload for special events.

pros:
* Encouraging environment that seeks to produce thoughtful students and vetted research
* Great culture outside of academics having many student organizations, a great city, and Division 1 sports
* Collaborative, friendly students
cons:
* Many students and faculty struggle with time management in juggling multiple roles
* Significant socioeconomic disparities can lead to social exclusion

review_title: As a student, this is the best place to study undergrad.
pros: The people are great here and I feel at home even when I'm not at home. I feel like I learn something new everyday and I am grateful for that.
cons: There is a lot of work as a student here, so it is tough to juggle extracurriculars with a social life and intense academic schedule. Time management is the most important aspect of having success here.

pros: Naturally I can only comment on the department I worked in so... Wonderful people who became a second family.   Flexible and an all-around great place to work with good benefits.  Inclusive and supportive.  Beautiful campus in the heart of Nashville.
cons: Some upper management changes were not good moves - hopefully now, those mistakes have been rectified by replacing those who harmed the sense of community.   Other than that, no cons.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros:
Top notch education
Top notch research
Opportunities for collaboration
Generally good work environment
cons:
[As with most universities] 
Graduate students are paid/treated like the bottom of the totem pole and well under their "fair market value" if you will. 
Good management is lacking.
Politics rule.
Benefits/insurance are dismal.

pros:
Vanderbilt has HR down to a science, regardless of position it seems. 

As far as the technical staff, it can be a little hit or miss which is related to what group you are in. That being said, the good groups are great. Low stress, easy deadlines, and you could really focus in on detail and not be in crunch mode every other week.
cons: Parking sucks. Remote work policy (at the time) was questionable.

review_title: Excellent people in an amazing city.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: Collaborations are abundant.  The city is beautiful and the people are very nice.  The engineering school is top 50 in the nation (with some departments cracking the top 10).
cons: As a graduate student, the insurance benefits are minimal and the university has a lot of fee's for taking classes.  Parking is also quite expensive.

pros: Great Benefits and nice campus
cons: There are too many layers of management at VU and also dysfunction in certain areas like Provost Office, one particular area that is not great is Provost Office Research

review_title: Not the place to be in I.T.
pros: The benefits are still better than most places.  The major IT groups are now one Vanderbilt wide, it least in name.
cons: Management by fear and intimidation.  The benefits keep getting scaled back.

pros: Vanderbilt offers great benefits, like affordable healthcare, tuition reimbursement and discounts at local places. Working for Vanderbilt looks great on a resume because other employers know how difficult it is to get hired on at Vanderbilt. Great work life balance.
cons: Sometimes you can feel like a cog in a machine.  In my department, there has been limited opportunity for professional development because of budget. Raises are rare, bonuses never happen.

pros: While few places are perfect in every way, Vanderbilt succeeds in creating an excellent research environment. Lots of interaction and opportunities to share thoughts. Lots of core labs for sharing advanced technology and equipment so smaller labs don't have to buy expensive stuff.
cons: Highly regulated and paid by strict guidelines. I wish there was more flexibility in individual pay according to contribution and not just education and time of experience.

pros: i do not care for the benefits.  they aren't what they were even a few hours ago.  and, we are about to lose some of our paid time off going with PTO.
cons: I am underpaid in my role.  as most are at vanderbilt whether university or med center.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Nashville, TN
pros: Competitive salaries for postdocs, extremely supportive colleagues, good benefits. I haven't interacted with a lot of departments, but generally the staff support seems pretty good.
cons: It's tough to be a postdoc anywhere, there isn't the same sense of community as with grad students or faculty. Most employees are on the hospital side, so it can feel a little lonely to be a non-student on the university side of campus.

review_title: Good company, limited chance for advancement
pros: Overall, good benefits and a solid company. I enjoyed the people that I worked alongside.
cons: Raises are almost nonexistent, so be sure to negotiate for a higher starting salary.  Also, double-check that there are not relatives working in your department-Vanderbilt allows this as long as they do not direct report to one another, but it can create serious issues within the working team.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: Beautiful campus, great reputation for academics, world-class medical center right there, close to downtown.
cons: Cost of living isn't cheap, but certainly not as bad as, say, NYC.

review_title: Great for doing homework, horrible hours and wages. I worked at the student rec center
pros:
Get to do homework on the job
The job is super easy and relaxed, most of the time
cons:
Management is horrible
Wages are terrible and there's no chance to move up 
The patrons are not very friendly and can be very rude
Can't get time off

pros: Clear instructions and oversight, engaging work, fun work environment. Overall a great place to work for the summer or school year to pick up some extra cash. Also, particularly good for extroverts as it often requires interaction with walk-in guests and prospective families
cons: Occasional early mornings during the summer for PreVu days, but certainly not the worst thing in the world.

pros: Vanderbilt University is a one of the top rated universities for education. It is a great place to network and the environment is aesthetically pleasing as well.
cons: It is sometimes said that Vanderbilt University could be viewed as living inside its own bubble separate from the rest of Nashville.

pros: Working with students is great. Fellow staff build collaborative relationships.
cons: Staff are not respected or seen as a vital part of the university. We are under paid (while faculty and administration make 2-20 times what we do depending), not considered or consulted in decision making that impacts us or that we are experts in, and repeatedly asked to take on more work when the university lays off other staff.

review_title: An inviting community and good opportunity to increase my skill set
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Nashville, TN
pros: Motivated researchers, world-class facilities, good benefits package, strong presence in the community, located in a great city, good educational environment
cons: Some buildings in need of repair, small gym area for faculty/staff (but this is expected to be expanded in the next couple years)

pros: Great sense of community, management is great, cares about your input, friendly stuff, and flexible.
cons: Harder to get raises especially if you are close to "max out" on your pay cap.  Do not often recognize employees for accomplishments or a  job well done.

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Nashville, TN
pros: Vanderbilt's Physics department cares about its graduate students, and doesn't see them as dollar signs like other schools. If you are accepted and put in the effort, listening to your advisor, you should have no trouble succeeding in the PhD program.
cons: Some of the older professors are racist. Others, however, founded programs (such as the Bridge Program) to combat racism. Its a mixed bag.

pros: The benefits are good and if you stay there are community perks as well.  If you work there long enough, there are tuition benefits for your children.
cons: red tape, bureaucracy...as in many places.  A lot of hiring is done internally so it is often very hard to get hired unless you know someone.

job_title: Research Assistant I in Nashville, TN
pros: Friendly staff, fantastic research opportunities, good opportunity to network and succeed.
cons: Interdepartmental research is difficult. Work life balance is always going to skewed in favor of work but I think coming to a university that is expected. Perks are that you get a chance to conduct and participate in research that is state-of-the-art and a chance to collaborate with some of the leading industries.

pros:
Status the name it holds in community
Transplant facility if ever needed that
Large employer
cons:
